questions.text: Which of the following is used in first line management of postmenopausal osteoporosis:
questions.solution:
Bisphosphonates are used in the first-line management of postmenopausal osteoporosis.

Mechanism of action :-

  • Bisphosphonates are structurally similar to pyrophosphates and are incorporated into the bone matrix.
  • They decrease bone resorption by impairing osteoclast function.
  • Bisphosphonates concentrate at sites of active remodeling. They remain in the matrix until the bone is remodeled. Then, they are released in the acid environment of the resorption lacunae and induce apoptosis in osteoclasts.
  • Osteoclasts internalize bisphosphonates as they are released along with calcium from the bone surface and then reduces osteoclast activity by
    • Promoting apoptosis of osteoclasts
    • Disrupting the cytoskeleton and ruffled border of osteoclasts
    • Inhibiting the differentiation of osteoclasts
  • The bisphosphonates approved for the treatment of osteoporosis are alendronate, risedronate, ibandronate, and zoledronate

Alendronate and risedronate can be administered daily or weekly with different dosages. Ibandronate can be administered daily, weekly or quarterly and Zoledronate is administered annually.

Indications for bisphosphonates :-

  • Osteoporosis
  • Paget’s disease
  • Hypercalcemia of malignancy
  • Osteolytic bone metastasis

Administration :-

Bisphosphonates are not recommended to be administered with food to minimise esophageal irritation.

Oral bisphosphonates have very limited bioavailability (<1-10%). Bisphosphonates are recommended to be administered after an overnight fast with a full glass of water at least 30 minutes before breakfast. Remaining upright for 30 minutes after dosing and proton pump inhibitors at bedtime can decrease the symptoms

Adverse Effects:

  • Osteonecrosis of the jaw is associated with the use of bisphosphonates 
  • Atypical femur fracture - occurs in the subtrochanteric femoral region or along the shaft distal to the lesser trochanter.

questions.text: A patient with a history of peptic ulcer underwent upper GI endoscopic biopsy of the stomach. The biopsy is stained with a special stain and shown in the image. What is the special stain used?
questions.solution:
The given slide shows the GI mucosa, which has been stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain, demonstrating the bacilli (Helicobacter pylori) causing type B gastritis.

On antral biopsy, H. pylori organisms are seen abundantly within the surface mucus layer, but they are difficult to visualize with routine hematoxylin (H&E) stains. Organisms are most easily demonstrated with special stains like Warthin starry silver stain or Giemsa stain.

Type B gastritis 

  • Type B gastritis is associated with H. pylori.
  • It commonly affects the antrum.
  • Intestinal metaplasia is associated with chronic pan-gastritis with atrophy.
  • Intestinal metaplasia with dysplasia has malignant potential.

H. pylori infection is also a risk factor for the following:

  • Peptic ulcer disease (duodenal > gastric)
  • Gastric adenocarcinoma
  • Gastric lymphoma

Image: Warthin-Starry silver stain showing Helicobacter pylori colonized on the surface of the regenerative epithelium.

Image: Giemsa stain showing Helicobacter pylori in a case of chronic gastritis.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in Pathology and Microbiology

von Kossa method Demonstrate calcium
Van Gieson stain

Demonstrate collagen in spindle-cell neoplasm; Delineate extent of fibrosis; Differentiate amyloid from collagen
Masson trichrome stain Demonstrate collagen and muscle in connective tissue disorders, muscle and fibroblast tumors, liver cirrhosis, neuromuscular diseases
Reticulin stain Demonstrate reticulin fibers to distinguish epithelial from non-epithelial neoplasm, Hodgkin's lymphoma, early cirrhosis of the liver, myelofibrosis
Verhoeff's method Demonstrate elastic fibers in malignant hypertension, arteriovenous malformation aneurysms, Marfan's syndrome, emphysema lung
Oil red O Sudan Black Sudan III/IV Demonstrate fat/lipids: Fatty liver-fat embolism-fibroma vs. thecoma of the ovary-liposarcoma

questions.text: Which of the following parasites may cause deficiency of vitamin B12?
questions.solution:
Diphyllobothrium latum causes deficiency of vitamin B12

The anemia develops because the tapeworm absorbs a large quantity of Vitamin B12 and interferes with its ileal absorption leading to Vitamin B12 deficiency. In severe cases, patients may exhibit neurologic sequelae of vitamin B12 deficiency.

Diphyllobothrium latum is also known as Fish tapeworm or Broad tapeworm.

  • The first intermediate host is freshwater crustacean, while the second intermediate host is freshwater fish.
  • The definitive hosts are man, dog, and cat.

The infective form to humans is the third stage plerocercoid larvae. It possesses a rudimentary scolex. The adult worm lives inside the small intestine and lays operculated eggs. These freshly passed eggs contain an immature embryo surrounded by yolk granules. This hexacanth embryo with 6 hooklets inside the egg is called Oncosphere.

 

Related Pearl: Infective form and diagnostic forms - Worms

Parasite Infective form Diagnostic form
Cestode
Diphyllobothrium latum Plerocercoid larva eggs or segments of the tapeworm
Taenia saginata Cysticercus bovis Egg
Taenia solium Cysticercus cellulosae Egg (for intestital taeniasis ) / cysticercus cellulosae larva (for cysticercosis)
Echinococcus granulosus Egg protoscolices and brood capsules
Hymenolepsis nana Egg Egg
TREMATODE
Schistosoma Cercariae Nonoperculated Eggs
Other trematodes - Fasciola hepatica, Fasciolopsis buski, Paragonimus westermani, Clonorchis sinensis Metacercaria larva Operculated Eggs
NEMATODE
Ascaris lumbricoides Egg Unembryonated eggs in stool
Hookworm Filariform larva eggs (in fresh stool), larva ( in old stool )
Strongyloides Filariform larva Rhabditiform larva
Trichuris Embryonated Egg Unembryonated Egg
Enterobius Egg Eggs from perianal skin
Filarial nematodes Third stage Filarial larva (L3) Microfilariae
Trichinella spiralis First stage larva (L1) Trichinella antibody test
Drancunculus medinensis Third stage filariform larva (L3) Adult worm
HINT: The infective and diagnostic forms are usually the same in the parasites causing AUTOINFECTION.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man presented with progressive swelling of the lower end of the femur. X-ray of this patient shows a Codman triangle. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young patient with a tumour in the distal femur with a Codmnan's triangle on X-ray suggests a probable diagnosis of osteosarcoma. 

Osteosarcoma is the most common non-hematologic primary malignancy of bone. It occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. It is typically metaphyseal. The distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus are common sites.

In osteosarcoma, the tumour lifts the periosteum and incites an intense periosteal reaction. The periosteal reaction is irregular and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance on x-ray.

The x-ray would show the following features.

  • Irregular destruction in the metaphysis is overshadowed by the formation of new bone
  • Lifting of the periosteum due to the formation of new bone inciting a periosteal reaction
  • Bone formation along the blood vessels within the tumour centrifugally gives rise to a sunburst (sunray) appearance on the radiograph.

Treatment: Osteosarcoma is treated by neoadjuvant chemotherapy, wide excision or radical surgery followed by adjuvant chemotherapy. Since here safe margins are difficult to achieve limb ablation is done. 

The goal of neoadjuvant and adjuvant chemotherapy is to treat micrometastasis.

T-10 protocol of chemotherapy is used in the management of osteosarcoma. It involves:

  • High-dose methotrexate and Citrovorum factor rescue
  • Adriamycin
  • BCD (bleomycin, cyclophosphamide, dactinomycin/doxorubicin)

Option A: Aneurysmal bone cysts are blood-filled spaces separated by fibrous septae. X-ray shows expansile lytic lesions in the metaphyses of the upper tibia. 

Option B: Ewing Sarcoma- lesion with poorly marginated edges in the diaphysis of the bone. The lamellated periosteal reaction in diaphysis is suggestive of Ewing’s sarcoma which is a highly radiosensitive tumour.

Option D: Osteoid osteoma is a benign tumour which occurs in the diaphyses of the femur. Classically, the pain is relieved after using NSAID. Codman's triangle is not seen.

Related Pearl: Classical radiological appearance of bone tumors

RADIOLOGICAL APPEARANCE

Ewing’s sarcoma but can be seen in any Malignant lesion or chronic osteomyelitis

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is an example of point mutation?
questions.solution:
• The classic example of point mutation is sickle-cell disease.
  • This is a T-to-A DNA substitution, which in turn results in an A-to-U change in the mRNA corresponding to the sixth codon of the β-globin gene (Glutamic acid being replaced by valine).
  • Defective production of β-globin results in a variety of diseases and is due to many different lesions in and around the β-globin gene.

A point mutation is a change in which a single base is substituted with a different base. These are of two types:

  1. Missense mutations
  2. Non-sense mutations

1. Missense mutations: These mutations may involve alteration of a single base in a triplet of bases and lead to the replacement of one amino acid by another in the gene product.                                                                                                                                                      Based on the substituted amino acid coded, the missense mutations are again of two types:

a) Conservative missense mutation: The substituted amino acid is biochemically similar to the original. It typically causes little change.

b) Non-conservative missense mutation: This type of mutation replaces the normal amino acid with a biochemically different one. An example of this type of mutation is sickle-cell anemia.

2. Nonsense mutations: It is a point mutation in a sequence of DNA that results in a premature stop codon. For example, β0 thalassemia.

Other options:

Hereditary spherocytosis (HS) is an inherited disorder caused by intrinsic defects in the red cell membrane skeleton that render red cells spheroid less deformable and vulnerable to splenic sequestration and destruction.

Related Pearl: Structural Alterations of the β -Globin Gene

Alteration

Function affected

Disease

Point Mutation

Protein folding

Sickle cell disease

Transcriptional control

β-Thalassemia

Frameshift & nonsense mutations

β-Thalassemia

RNA processing

β-Thalassemia

Deletion

mRNA production

β0-Thalassemia

Hemoglobin Lepore

Rearrangement

mRNA production

β-Thalassemia type III

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady comes with abnormal uterine bleeding. Hysterectomy was performed and the following specimen was  retrieved. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The specimen is of a Leiomyoma.

The uterine body / corpus is enlarged and deformed. The cut surface shows multiple nodules, well-circumscribed, firm, white-greyish with a whorled appearance formed by the intersecting bundles of brown muscle fibers and white fibrous tissue. Leiomyomas can also present bleeding areas, cystic degeneration and calcifications. The uterine cavity is compressed.

Menstrual symptoms of fibroid includes:

  • Menorrhagia, polymenorrhoea, metrorrhagia, continuous or postmenopausal bleeding
  • Dysmenorrhea
  • Infertility, recurrent abortions
  • Pain
  • Pressure symptoms
  • Abdominal lump
  • Vaginal discharge

Drugs to reduce the size of the fibroid:

  • Antiprogesterone – Mifepristone/RU-486
  • Danazol (Usually not used due to androgenic side effects)
  • GnRH 
    • Agonists – goserelin, leuprorelin, nafarelin, busereli
    • Antagonists – cetrorelix, ganirelix
  • Selective progesterone receptor modulator (SPRM’s) – Ulipristal, Asoprisnil

Other medical methods to treat fibroids include:

  • Levonorgestrel IUD- controls bleeding effectively
  • Combined oral contraceptives
  • DMPA
  • Tranexamic acid
  • Iron therapy for anemia
  • Selective estrogen-receptor modulators (SERMs) like tibolone and raloxifene are used as add-back therapy along with GnRH treatment. They reduce associated vasomotor symptoms and bone loss.

Radiological interventions for fibroids:

  • Uterine artery Embolization - Angiographic interventional procedure where polyvinyl alcohol microspheres are introduced into both uterine arteries, producing ischemia and necrosis of the fibroid.
  • Magnetic Resonance guided Focused Ultrasound - Ultrasound energy is focused to cause coagulative necrosis in selected fibroids.

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy

  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration

  • Red degeneration

  • Sarcomatous change

  • Torsion, hemorrhage

  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp

  • Inversion of the uterus

  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma

  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia

  • Accompanying adenomyosis

  • Parasitic fibroid

questions.text: Most common site of origin for nasopharyngeal carcinoma is
questions.solution:
Commonest site of origin for nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmüller.

  • Epstein–Barr Virus (EBV) is closely associated with nasopharyngeal cancer.
  • EB virus has two important antigens: Viral capsid antigen (VCA) and Early antigen (EA).
  • IgA antibodies against both EA and VCA should be done for screening of patients for nasopharyngeal cancer.

Presenting symptoms and signs of nasopharyngeal cancer in order of frequency are:

  • Cervical lymphadenopathy (most common) (60–90%)
  • Hearing loss
  • Nasal obstruction
  • Epistaxis
  • Cranial nerve palsies -Cranial nerves V and VI are the most commonly involved among all the cranial nerves. 
  • Headache
  • Earache
  • Neck pain
  • Weight loss

Trotter’s Triad:

  1. Conductive hearing loss
  2. Immobility of homolateral soft palate
  3. Trigeminal neuralgia

Pathology:

 Gross image would either be ulcerative or proliferative or infiltrative, cystic presentation is not seen. Microscopy would reveal squamous cell carcinoma or anaplastic variety and ectodermal features are seen. 

Radiotherapy is the treatment of choice for nasopharyngeal cancer.

  • Stage I and II are treated by radiotherapy alone.
  • Stage III and IV require concomitant radiation and chemotherapy or radiation followed by chemotherapy
  • Radical neck dissection can be done in case of recurrent or residual disease.

questions.text: A patient presented with the complaints of chest pain. Which among the following is the best investigation to diagnose MI within 2-4 hours?
questions.solution:
Measurement of Troponin is the best investigation to diagnose MI within 2-4 hours.

Troponin T and Troponin I

  • These are the proteins that mediate calcium-mediated contraction of the cardiac and the skeletal muscles.
  • They are highly specific for MI.
  • Troponins will remain elevated longer than creatine kinase (CK), for up to 14 days.

Creatine phosphokinase (CK): 

  • CK rises within 4–8 h and generally returns to normal by 48–72 h. However, CK is non-specific, as it may be elevated with skeletal muscle disease or trauma, including intramuscular injection. The MB isoenzyme of CK (CK-MB) is not significantly found in the extracardiac tissue, and is more specific.

Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)

  • Normally, serum levels of LDH2 is greater than those of LDH1; but, in MI, LDH1 is more than LDH2. This is called flipping of the LDH ratio.
  • Current recommendations suggest that LDH no longer has a role in the diagnosis of MI.

Related Pearl: Cardiac Biomarkers

Cardiac biomarker

Rise

Peak

Return to baseline

CK-MB

2-4 hours

24 hours

48-72 hours

Troponin T and I

2-4 hours

Troponin T 24-48 hours

Troponin I- max at 24 hours 

7-10 days

LDH

24 hours

3-6 days

2 weeks

SGOT

12 hours

48 hours

4-5 days

questions.text: Which of the following is an important sign of antemortem drowning:
questions.solution:
An important sign of antemortem drowning is cadaveric spasm which manifests as weed, grass ,sticks etc. floating in the water being firmly grasped in the hands. When present, it is an important sign suggesting that the victim struggled for existence while in water.

 Features like emphysema aquosum, froth in the air passages, hemorrhage into the middle ears, and subpleural hemorrhages are seen in cases of drowning. Overinflation of the lungs in drowning is known as emphysema aquosum. The edema fluid in the bronchi blocks the passive collapse that normally occurs at death, holding the lungs in the inspiratory position. In drowning this may be sufficient to mark the lateral surfaces of the lungs with the impression of the ribs, leaving visible and palpable grooves after removal of the organs from the thorax. This is a valuable positive sign of drowning to be gained at autopsy.

Autopsy findings in drowning:

  • Froth in the air passages - The most useful autopsy sign in drowning. It consists of a proteinaceous exudate and surfactant mixed with the water of the drowning medium.
  • Waterlogging of the lung - Frothy fluid will exude from the bronchi when the lung is squeezed and from the cut surfaces when they are sectioned with a knife. But, absence of waterlogging by no means excludes true drowning (e.g. dry drowning).
  • Emphysema aqueosum - Overinflation of the lungs.
  • Paltauf’s spots - Subpleural haemorrhages that probably reflect haemolysis within intra-alveolar haemorrhages, and have been described in 50–60% of drownings.
  • Dilation of right heart and great veins - This is a very subjective and non-specific finding.
  • Foreign material in stomach - The stomach may contain watery fluid or even foreign material from the water, such as silt, weed or sand. This is also not a finding which can diagnose drowning.
  • Haemorrhage into the middle ears and into the temporal bone - This has been postulated as a positive sign of drowning, it is a non-specific finding.
  • Presence of fluid in the middle ear or paranasal sinuses - Also not a reliable diagnostic sign of drowning.

Note - Thus, the autopsy findings in drowning are mostly nonspecific and none give conclusive evidence of drowning. The most useful one is froth in the air passages.

Related Pearl: Differentiating features between Antemortem amd Postmortem drowning

       Antemortem drowning       Postmortem drowning
Foam/froth at nostrils or mouth Not present
Cadaveric spasm Not present
Lungs usually are voluminous, bulky, water-logged and over-inflated ,called as emphysema aquosum. Passive collection of water  in the lungs without any formation of columns of froth,has been called as oedema aquosum.
Presence of foam, fluid, debris, weeds, vegetation, etc. in the bronchi and bronchioles. Foreign matter may passively find access only to the upper respiratory passage.
Demonstration of diatoms in the lungs, liver, brain, bone marrow, etc. Diatoms may reach the lungs but not to the distant organs because of absence of circulation.
Stomach may contain water and foreign material like sand, weed, dirt etc which may be swallowed while struggling for life. Water could enter the stomach. However, quantity of foreign matter may become the decisive issue.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presented with complaints of bed-wetting almost twice a week for the past 1 year. A detailed investigation was done to rule out the organic cause. What should be the treatment plan for this child?

choices.text: Bladder training (with reward for delaying micturition during daytime)
Bell and pad based classical conditioning

questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of nocturnal enuresis. Bell and pad based classical conditioning is the most effective treatment.

Nocturnal enuresis refers to the occurrence of involuntary urination at night after 5 years of age. It may be a normal phenomenon in children up to 5 years of age.

Treatment for nocturnal enuresis may include either behavioural therapy, pharmacotherapy, or psychotherapy.

Behavioural therapy:

  • Classic conditioning with the bell (or buzzer) and pad (alarm) apparatus is the most effective treatment for enuresis.
  • Dryness is achieved in 50% of the cases.
  • Bladder training with encouragement or reward for delaying micturition for increasing times during waking hours is useful but considered as an inferior to bell and pad.

Pharmacotherapy:

  • Medications should be considered if behavioural therapy has failed, and if enuresis is causing impairment in social, family, and school function.
  • Desmopressin (an antidiuretic) and Reboxetine (norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor) are commonly used drugs. Reboxetine is considered as a safer alternative to imipramine.

Psychotherapy:

  • It is indicated in cases with chronic enuresis, to deal with any coexisting psy­chiatric problems and the emotional and family difficulties.

questions.text: A 3-year child is brought to the pediatrician for the evaluation of the lateral neck mass. On examination, a painless, soft, fluctuating mass is found in the lateral side of the neck as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A soft, painless, fluctuating mass found in the posterior part of the neck in a child, is most likely to be a cystic hygroma.

Cystic hygroma is a lymph filled sac that results from the obstruction of the lymph vessels during their development. It is most commonly present in the posterior triangle of the neck. The mass may be apparent at birth or may appear in early childhood due to the increased accumulation of lymph. Since the sac is filled with lymph, it is soft, fluctuating, and brilliantly transilluminant.

Treatment:

  • Lymphangiomas are treated by surgical excision and image-guided sclerotherapy.
  • Initially, surgical excision is done to safely remove the lymphatic malformation without causing any damage to the adjacent vital tissues such as blood vessels, nerves, or muscles.
  • For large tumors and the tumors that extend to the base of the tongue or floor of the mouth, combined sclerotherapy and surgical resection are done.
  • If there is any residual lymphatic malformation after the treatment, then a conservative excision or unroofing of the cyst is done. It may be combined with sclerosing therapy or repeated partial excisions.

Note: The terms lymphangioma and cystic hygromas are older terms. They are now called lymphatic malformations.

Option B: A thyroglossal duct cyst is a congenital midline neck swelling that typically presents during childhood often noticed after an upper respiratory infection. Classically the cyst moves upwards on swallowing and on tongue protrusion. This indicates attachment to the hyoid bone and the swelling is smooth, soft, fluctuant (cystic), non-tender, mobile, and shows transillumination.

Option C : Ranula is a transilluminant mucocele. It is also known as "frog's belly", as it resembles the vocal sacs of a frog. It occurs due to an obstruction in the sublingual salivary gland. A ranula usually presents as a large, tense, bluish swelling on the floor of the mouth to one side on the midline. If the obstruction happens in the ducts of minor salivary glands such as labial or buccal, it is termed mucocele.

Option D: Cervical lymphadenopathy is seen in children with infections of the parotid and upper respiratory tract infections. On palpation, they are firm and non-fluctuant.

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient with history of hepatitis and behavioral changes is known to have an inborn error of metabolism. Ocular examination of this patient shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows Kayser–Fleisher ring, which is seen in Wilson’s disease.  

Kayser-Fleischer ring (KF) Ring:

  • KF ring is a golden-brown ring formed due to the deposition of copper in Descemet’s membrane of the cornea
  • Characteristically observed in Wilson's disease but is not pathognomonic
  • Does not interfere with vision
  • Present in almost all patients of Wilson's disease with neurological/psychiatric symptoms
  • Present only in 30–50% of patients diagnosed in the hepatic or presymptomatic state, therefore the absence of KF rings does not exclude the diagnosis of Wilson's disease.

Wilsons disease:

The autosomal-recessive disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which encodes a membrane-bound, copper-transporting ATPase.

Clinical symptoms:

  • Hepatitis and cirrhosis
  • Behavioral disturbances
  • Wing beating tremor
  • Ophthalmic characteristics:
    • Deposition of copper in the posterior capsule of the lens resulting in sunflower cataract
    • KF ring 

Diagnosis:

    • Presence of KF rings
    • Decreased serum ceruloplasmin (copper-containing enzyme/ferroxidase) levels
    • Measured hepatic copper levels in liver biopsy
    • Increased 24-hour urine copper excretion

The gold standard for diagnosis: Liver biopsy with quantitative copper assays

Treatment: Trientine and Zinc is the first choice of a drug regimen to be used for treating mild hepatic decompensation in Wilson’s disease.

Recommended drugs in Wilsons disease:

Disease Status First Choice Second Choice
Initial    

Hepatitis or Cirrhosis without decompensation

 Zinc Trientine
Hepatic decompensation    
Mild Trientine and Zinc Penicillamine and Zinc
Moderate Trientine and Zinc Hepatic transplantation
Severe Hepatic Transplantation Trientine and Zinc
Initial neurological/Psychiatric Tetrathiomolybdate and Zinc Zinc
Maintenance Zinc Trientine
Presymptomatic Zinc Trientine

questions.text: Foot drop along with loss of eversion is caused by damage to:
questions.solution:
Foot drop with loss of eversion is caused by damage to the common peroneal nerve.

The common peroneal nerve is a component of the sciatic nerve. In the posterior thigh, it supplies the short head of biceps femoris. It curves around the neck of fibula deep to peroneus longus and divides into superficial and deep peroneal nerves.

  • The superficial peroneal nerve innervates peroneus longus and peroneus brevis which are the evertors of foot and to the skin over dorsal area of foot except the first webspace and lateral side of little toe.
  • The deep peroneal nerve innervates all muscles of anterior compartment which are the dorsiflexors of foot, extensor digitorum brevis, first two dorsal interossei muscles and skin between great and second toes.

Common peroneal nerve is closely related to neck of the fibula and hence the nerve is commonly injured in fracture involving this area.

Injury to common peroneal nerve will lead to:

  • Weakness of dorsiflexion of foot or foot drop
  • Loss of eversion
  • Loss of extension of toes
  • Sensory loss along the anterior and lateral side of the leg, dorsum of foot including the medial side of great toe.

Note: Injury to the deep peroneal nerve will cause foot drop with intact eversion.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male with chronic kidney disease comes for a routine follow-up. His chest X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a mitral annular calcification. It is a chronic degenerative process affecting the mitral valve ring and can be a rheumatic sequela. 

The clinical vignette gives clues towards the multiple co-morbidities and complications that may be associated with MAC. 

  • Stroke
  • Atherosclerosis
  • Chronic Kidney Disease 
  • Mitral Regurgitation 
  • Mitral Stenosis 
  • Arrhythmias, atrial fibrillation 
  • Endocarditis 
  • Aortic Stenosis 

Surgical treatment is indicated only if concomitant stenosis or regurgitation is to be corrected. Severe MAC makes the surgery difficult. Isolated MAC does not require endocarditis prophylaxis. Anti-coagulation and anti-platelet medications are recommended within the guidelines of treatment of the comorbid conditions. 

Other options:

In aortic sclerosis, there can be aortic valvular calcifications with cardiomegaly. Signs of heart failure such as pulmonary venous congestion and pulmonary interstitial/alveolar edema can be seen. 

Atrial Myxomas have non-specific x-ray findings- 

  • Cardiomegaly: left atrial enlargement
  • Intracardiac tumoral calcification
  • Mitral valve obstruction evidence 
  • Elevated left atrial pressure findings- pulmonary edema

A calcified atrial thrombus is a rare entity that may show up as calcified lesions in the cardiac shadow on a chest x-ray. They are usually discovered by transthoracic echocardiography.

questions.text: A healthy child is brought to the pediatrician for a routine check-up. The child comes in with a toy in her hand and readily shares it with the doctor. She is able to say her name. Her mother says she does most of her activities with her right hand now. If she is given a paper and pen, which of the following will she be able to do?
questions.solution:
This child who is able to say her name, shares toys, and has developed handedness is around three years of age and she will be able to copy a circle.

Developmental milestones at the age of three:

Social and Emotional:

These children usually copy adults and friends, engage in cooperative play, show affection for friends and concern for crying friends without prompts, understand the concept of ownership but are able to share toys, show a wide range of emotions, and may get upset with changes in routine easily.

Language and Communication:

Follow instructions with two/three steps, can name most things around them, understand prepositions, use pronouns, name friends and make a simple conversation with two sentences.

Cognitive:

Copy a circle with a crayon, turn book pages one at a time, build towers with six or more blocks, screw and unscrew jars/lids and can do puzzles with four or fewer pieces

Motor:

Climb well, run easily, pedal a tricycle and walk up and down stairs with one foot on each step

 

Related Pearl: Important developmental milestones at various ages

Developmental Milestones
At 1 year
  • Motor: Walks with support
  • Adaptive: Mature pincer grasp
  • Language: Speaks a few words
  • Social: Plays simple ball game
  • Domestic mimicry at 18 months
At 2 years
  • Motor: Walks up and downstairs, one step at a time
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 6 blocks 
  • Language: Simple sentences, a vocabulary of 50-100 words, uses pronouns at 2.5 yrs
  • Social: Asks for food and starts toilet training, listens to stories
At 3 years
  • Motor: Rides tricycle
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 9 blocks, handedness is established
  • Language: Knows full name, age, gender
  • Social: Plays simple games and engages in parallel play with other children
At 4 years
  • Motor: Hops
  • Adaptive: Draws square and constructs a bridge with blocks
  • Language: Tells stories
  • Social: Goes to the toilet alone
At 5 years
  • Motor: Skips
  • Adaptive: Draws a triangle
  • Language: Asks the meaning of words, names 4 colors
  • Social: Dresses and undresses
